elements.content: Three Co­(II) metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) were synthesized employing a rational design approach. On the basis of the different structures of three complexes, we tested their absorption properties toward two anionic dyes. The absorption results indicate that not only uncoordinated functional groups in the structure play an important role in adsorbing capacity but also physical forces can affect absorbing ability. Water stability testing shows that three crystals display high stability in aqueous solutions with different pH values. To our delight, the framework integrity of three complexes can be well-retained even after absorbing dyes.
elements.clean_text: Three Co(II) metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) were synthesized employing a rational design approach. On the basis of the different structures of three complexes, we tested their absorption properties toward two anionic dyes. The absorption results indicate that not only uncoordinated functional groups in the structure play an important role in adsorbing capacity but also physical forces can affect absorbing ability. Water stability testing shows that three crystals display high stability in aqueous solutions with different pH values. To our delight, the framework integrity of three complexes can be well-retained even after absorbing dyes.

elements.content: Three cobalt metal−organic frameworks (MOFs) were synthesized. On the basis of the different structures of three complexes, their adsorption capacity toward Congo red and methyl orange was studied in detail. The results demonstrated that uncoordinated functional groups in the structure played a significant role in the adsorbing capacity.
elements.clean_text: Three cobalt metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) were synthesized. On the basis of the different structures of three complexes, their adsorption capacity toward Congo red and methyl orange was studied in detail. The results demonstrated that uncoordinated functional groups in the structure played a significant role in the adsorbing capacity.

elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have always been a hot research topic in materials science not only because of their charming and diverse structures but also for their comprehensive applications in luminescence, magnetic property, gas storage, molecular sensing and separation, and ion exchange. Until now, intensive researches have been performed to make the properties clear. For instance, gas sorption and drug delivery mainly depend on the pore features of MOFs, including the pore shape and size and functional groups distribution, while molecular sensing and luminescence depend on the component of the MOFs, which could be directly applied in chemical sensing. Therefore, it is still a challenging work to synthesize and modify functional MOFs in host–guest interactions.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have always been a hot research topic in materials science not only because of their charming and diverse structures but also for their comprehensive applications in luminescence, magnetic property, gas storage, molecular sensing and separation, and ion exchange. Until now, intensive researches have been performed to make the properties clear. For instance, gas sorption and drug delivery mainly depend on the pore features of MOFs, including the pore shape and size and functional groups distribution, while molecular sensing and luminescence depend on the component of the MOFs, which could be directly applied in chemical sensing. Therefore, it is still a challenging work to synthesize and modify functional MOFs in host-guest interactions.

elements.content: Dyes, toxic and carcinogenic, are generally difficult to degrade, because they are highly stable to light and oxidation. Thus, dyes removal from contaminated water attracts the attention of the majority of researchers. Tamara L. Church’s group reported an amino-functionalized MOF amino-MIL-101­(Al) that has excellent sorption amount for methyl orange. Zhang’s group synthesized a nanostructured ZIF-8 on silica microspheres displaying degradation of methyl orange due to the surface functionalities (−SH, −COOH, and −NH2). Hence, we can conclude that functional groups can affect adsorbing capacity. However, the effect of uncoordinated oxygen atoms and uncoordinated carboxyl groups in dye removal was rarely reported in the literature.
elements.clean_text: Dyes, toxic and carcinogenic, are generally difficult to degrade, because they are highly stable to light and oxidation. Thus, dyes removal from contaminated water attracts the attention of the majority of researchers. Tamara L. Church's group reported an amino-functionalized MOF amino-MIL-101(Al) that has excellent sorption amount for methyl orange. Zhang's group synthesized a nanostructured ZIF-8 on silica microspheres displaying degradation of methyl orange due to the surface functionalities (-SH, -COOH, and -NH2). Hence, we can conclude that functional groups can affect adsorbing capacity. However, the effect of uncoordinated oxygen atoms and uncoordinated carboxyl groups in dye removal was rarely reported in the literature.

elements.content: In this work, we reported three Co­(II) MOFs, namely, [Co­(L)] n (1), {[Co­(L)­(BIBP)]·H2O} n (2), {[Co3(L)­(BPY)1.5]·H2O} n (3; ). 1 has uncoordinated oxygen atoms in carboxyl groups, and 2 owns uncoordinated carboxyl groups, while 3 is totally coordinated. Here, we selected two kinds of anionic dyes, Congo red (CR) and methyl orange (MO), to investigate whether the uncoordinated functional groups can affect the adsorption capacity.
elements.clean_text: In this work, we reported three Co(II) MOFs, namely, [Co(L)] n  (1), {[Co(L)(BIBP)]⋅H2O} n  (2), {[Co3(L)(BPY)1.5]⋅H2O} n  (3; ). 1 has uncoordinated oxygen atoms in carboxyl groups, and 2 owns uncoordinated carboxyl groups, while 3 is totally coordinated. Here, we selected two kinds of anionic dyes, Congo red (CR) and methyl orange (MO), to investigate whether the uncoordinated functional groups can affect the adsorption capacity.

elements.clean_text: 1  Tricarboxylic Acid, BIBP, and BPY Ligands

elements.content:
The experimental section is listed in the . The detailed information on complexes 1–3 is summarized in .

Structure of [Co­(L)]<sub> <italic>n</italic> </sub>(<bold>1</bold>)

Single-crystal structure analysis reveals that 1 crystallizes in the orthorhombic crystal system with Pccn space group. The asymmetric unit of 1 contains one Co­(II) metal center and one L ligand (a). Each Co­(II) is coordinated by six oxygen atoms from six L ligands to form a distorted octahedron (b). The Co­(II) ions are connected by six L ligands to form a three-dimensional (3D) structure (c). To better understand the nature of this intricate framework, a topological approach was applied. We reduce multidimensional structures to simple nodes and connection nets. Co ions can be regarded as 6-connected nodes. Therefore, the whole structure can be represented as a new 3,6-connected network topology (with the point symbol {4·82}2{42·812·10}) (d).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

The experimental section is listed in the . The detailed information on complexes 1-3 is summarized in .

Structure of [Co(L)] n (1)

Single-crystal structure analysis reveals that 1 crystallizes in the orthorhombic crystal system with Pccn space group. The asymmetric unit of 1 contains one Co(II) metal center and one L ligand (a). Each Co(II) is coordinated by six oxygen atoms from six L ligands to form a distorted octahedron (b). The Co(II) ions are connected by six L ligands to form a three-dimensional (3D) structure (c). To better understand the nature of this intricate framework, a topological approach was applied. We reduce multidimensional structures to simple nodes and connection nets. Co ions can be regarded as 6-connected nodes. Therefore, the whole structure can be represented as a new 3,6-connected network topology (with the point symbol {4⋅82}2{42⋅812⋅10}) (d).

elements.content: (a) Coordination environment of 1. Symmetry code: No. 1 = −x + 2, −y + 1, −z + 1, No. 2 = x – 1, −y + 3/2, z + 1/2, No. 3 = −x + 1/2, y, z – 1/2, No. 4 = x + 1, −y + 3/2, z – 1/2, No. 5 = x – 1/2, y + 1/2, −z + 1, No. 6 = −x + 3/2, −y + 3/2, z. (b) The open hexagonal ring constructed by six L3– ligands and the mononuclear cobalt unit. (c) 3D framework of 1. (d) Topological representation of 1.
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) Coordination environment of 1. Symmetry code: No. 1 = -x + 2, -y + 1, -z + 1, No. 2 = x - 1, -y + 3/2, z + 1/2, No. 3 = -x + 1/2, y, z - 1/2, No. 4 = x + 1, -y + 3/2, z - 1/2, No. 5 = x - 1/2, y + 1/2, -z + 1, No. 6 = -x + 3/2, -y + 3/2, z. (b) The open hexagonal ring constructed by six L3- ligands and the mononuclear cobalt unit. (c) 3D framework of 1. (d) Topological representation of 1.

elements.content: Complex 2 reveals a two-dimensional (2D) structure and crystallizes in the triclinic crystal system of P1̅ space group. The asymmetric unit of 2 consists of one Co­(II) ion, one L ligand, one BIBP ligand, and one water molecule. Each Co­(II) ion is coordinated by four carboxylate oxygen atoms from three different L ligands and two nitrogen atoms from two BIBP ligands (a). There are three kinds of carboxyl groups of L ligand, one adopting bidentate bridging node to combine two Co­(II) ions, the other adopting bidentate chelating mode to chelate one Co­(II) ion. In addition, each L ligand owns an uncoordinated carboxylate acid. Pairs of Co­(II) cations are connected by two L ligands to generate a dinuclear Co2(CO2)2 secondary building unit (SBU) with a Co···Co separation of 4.756 Å. These Co2(CO2)2 SBUs are further bridged through the second symmetrical L ligand into a one-dimensional (1D) chain with a loop (b). Such 1D chains are further extended through the BIBP ligands from nearly perpendicular direction to furnish a 2D layer (c). Moreover, the packing diagram shows that the 2D networks are stacking parallel with ···AAA··· mode. The layers do not overlap with each other, so there are no channels in the crystal structure. From a topological perspective, the 2D layers can be simplified into (4,4)-connected sql nets with point symbol {44·62} (d).
elements.clean_text:
Structure of {[Co(L) (BIBP)]⋅H2O} n  (2)

Complex 2 reveals a two-dimensional (2D) structure and crystallizes in the triclinic crystal system of P1̅ space group. The asymmetric unit of 2 consists of one Co(II) ion, one L ligand, one BIBP ligand, and one water molecule. Each Co(II) ion is coordinated by four carboxylate oxygen atoms from three different L ligands and two nitrogen atoms from two BIBP ligands (a). There are three kinds of carboxyl groups of L ligand, one adopting bidentate bridging node to combine two Co(II) ions, the other adopting bidentate chelating mode to chelate one Co(II) ion. In addition, each L ligand owns an uncoordinated carboxylate acid. Pairs of Co(II) cations are connected by two L ligands to generate a dinuclear Co2(CO2)2 secondary building unit (SBU) with a Co⋅⋅⋅Co separation of 4.756 Å. These Co2(CO2)2 SBUs are further bridged through the second symmetrical L ligand into a one-dimensional (1D) chain with a loop (b). Such 1D chains are further extended through the BIBP ligands from nearly perpendicular direction to furnish a 2D layer (c). Moreover, the packing diagram shows that the 2D networks are stacking parallel with ⋅⋅⋅AAA⋅⋅⋅ mode. The layers do not overlap with each other, so there are no channels in the crystal structure. From a topological perspective, the 2D layers can be simplified into (4,4)-connected sql nets with point symbol {44⋅62} (d).

elements.content: (a) Coordination environment of 2. Symmetry code: No. 1 = −x + 1, −y, −z, No. 2 = x, y + 1, z, No. 3 = x – 1, y, z + 1, No. 4 = x, y – 1, z, No. 5 = x + 1, y, z −1. (b) Infinite 1D chain in 2. (upper) Constructed by H3L and Cobalt ions. (lower) Constructed by BIBP and cobalt ions. (c) A 2D bipillared layer in 2. (d) Schematic representation of an sql net for 2.
elements.clean_text: 2  (a) Coordination environment of 2. Symmetry code: No. 1 = -x + 1, -y, -z, No. 2 = x, y + 1, z, No. 3 = x - 1, y, z + 1, No. 4 = x, y - 1, z, No. 5 = x + 1, y, z -1. (b) Infinite 1D chain in 2. (upper) Constructed by H3L and Cobalt ions. (lower) Constructed by BIBP and cobalt ions. (c) A 2D bipillared layer in 2. (d) Schematic representation of an sql net for 2.

elements.content: Complex 3 displays a 3D structure and crystallizes in the triclinic crystal system of P1̅ space group. The asymmetric unit of 3 consists of three Co­(II) ion, one L ligand, and one and a half BPY ligands. As shown in a, there are two crystallographically independent Co­(II) centers (Co1 and Co2). The Co1 atom is six-coordinated by four oxygen atoms from three L ligands and two nitrogen atoms from two BPY ligands; L ligands link the Co1 cations to generate a dinuclear Co2(CO2)2 SBU with a Co···Co separation of 4.370 Å; Co2 ion is coordinated by four carboxylate oxygen atoms from two L ligands and two nitrogen atoms from two BPY ligands. In the structure, two carboxyl groups of L ligands adopt bidentate bridging node to combine four Co­(II) ions, while another carboxyl group adopts bidentate chelating mode to chelate one Co­(II) ion. In addition, there are two connection modes of BPY ligands, two parallel BPY ligands link the Co2(CO2)2 SBU, while another kind of BPY ligand adopts another mode to link the Co­(II) ions in the vertical direction (b). From the perspective of topology, the Co2(CO2)2 SBU can be simplified into a 6-connected node, the mononuclear Co­(II) cation can be regarded as a 4-connected node, and L ligand can be regarded as a 3-connected node. Thus, the 3D structure of 3 is characterized as a 3,4,6-connected network with the vertex symbol of {4·82}2­{42·68·83·9 × 10}­{8·93·102} (c).
elements.clean_text:
Structure of {[Co3(L) (BPY)1.5]⋅H2O} n  (3)

Complex 3 displays a 3D structure and crystallizes in the triclinic crystal system of P1̅ space group. The asymmetric unit of 3 consists of three Co(II) ion, one L ligand, and one and a half BPY ligands. As shown in a, there are two crystallographically independent Co(II) centers (Co1 and Co2). The Co1 atom is six-coordinated by four oxygen atoms from three L ligands and two nitrogen atoms from two BPY ligands; L ligands link the Co1 cations to generate a dinuclear Co2(CO2)2 SBU with a Co⋅⋅⋅Co separation of 4.370 Å; Co2 ion is coordinated by four carboxylate oxygen atoms from two L ligands and two nitrogen atoms from two BPY ligands. In the structure, two carboxyl groups of L ligands adopt bidentate bridging node to combine four Co(II) ions, while another carboxyl group adopts bidentate chelating mode to chelate one Co(II) ion. In addition, there are two connection modes of BPY ligands, two parallel BPY ligands link the Co2(CO2)2 SBU, while another kind of BPY ligand adopts another mode to link the Co(II) ions in the vertical direction (b). From the perspective of topology, the Co2(CO2)2 SBU can be simplified into a 6-connected node, the mononuclear Co(II) cation can be regarded as a 4-connected node, and L ligand can be regarded as a 3-connected node. Thus, the 3D structure of 3 is characterized as a 3,4,6-connected network with the vertex symbol of {4⋅82}2{42⋅68⋅83⋅9 × 10}{8⋅93⋅102} (c).

(b) The 3D framework of 3 and different connected mode of BPY ligands. (c) A view of 3,4,6-connected topology.

(b) The 3D framework of 3 and different connected mode of BPY ligands. (c) A view of 3,4,6-connected topology.

elements.content: Delightedly, the complexes 1–3 keep unchanged in air for a long time. To further explore the stability of complexes 1–3, they were soaked in aqueous solutions with different pH values. The result of powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns clearly demonstrated that the framework integrity of complexes 1–3 can be well-retained in pH = 1–14 aqueous solutions (). There is no doubt that the good stability of complexes 1–3 ensures their structures for further application.
elements.clean_text: Delightedly, the complexes 1-3 keep unchanged in air for a long time. To further explore the stability of complexes 1-3, they were soaked in aqueous solutions with different pH values. The result of powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns clearly demonstrated that the framework integrity of complexes 1-3 can be well-retained in pH = 1-14 aqueous solutions (). There is no doubt that the good stability of complexes 1-3 ensures their structures for further application.

elements.content: There are obvious differences of coordination modes between three complexes. For 1, each carboxyl group of H3L has an uncoordinated oxygen atom. In 2, two of the three carboxyl groups of H3L coordinated with Co­(II) ions, while the remaining carboxyl group is not involved in coordination. For 3, each carboxyl group of H3L coordinated with Co­(II) ions. As we expected, the different structures can affect the adsorbing capacity.
elements.clean_text: There are obvious differences of coordination modes between three complexes. For 1, each carboxyl group of H3L has an uncoordinated oxygen atom. In 2, two of the three carboxyl groups of H3L coordinated with Co(II) ions, while the remaining carboxyl group is not involved in coordination. For 3, each carboxyl group of H3L coordinated with Co(II) ions. As we expected, the different structures can affect the adsorbing capacity.

elements.content: MOFs (5 mg) without any activation were dispersed in 5 mL water solutions of CR or MO in a 20 mL glass bottle in quadruplicate, which were treated by magnetic stirring for 10, 20, 30, and 40 min. Upon adsorption, the insoluble composite precipitate was separated by centrifuge, and the solution was detected at certain time intervals using UV–vis absorption spectroscopy.
elements.clean_text:
Dyes Adsorption and Mechanism

MOFs (5 mg) without any activation were dispersed in 5 mL water solutions of CR or MO in a 20 mL glass bottle in quadruplicate, which were treated by magnetic stirring for 10, 20, 30, and 40 min. Upon adsorption, the insoluble composite precipitate was separated by centrifuge, and the solution was detected at certain time intervals using UV-vis absorption spectroscopy.

elements.content: The adsorption results of three complexes toward the two kinds of anionic dyes are shown in . As shown in a–c, the CR was totally absorbed for MOF-1 and MOF-2 after 40 min; however, the ability of MOF-3 to adsorb CR is almost negligible. The UV–vis curves of d–f indicate only MOF-2 exhibiting an excellent capacity to absorb MO, while MOF-1 and MOF-3 exhibit no obvious adsorption for MO.
elements.clean_text: The adsorption results of three complexes toward the two kinds of anionic dyes are shown in . As shown in a-c, the CR was totally absorbed for MOF-1 and MOF-2 after 40 min; however, the ability of MOF-3 to adsorb CR is almost negligible. The UV-vis curves of d-f indicate only MOF-2 exhibiting an excellent capacity to absorb MO, while MOF-1 and MOF-3 exhibit no obvious adsorption for MO.

elements.content: (left) Photographic images and UV–vis spectra of CR in water at various time intervals. (a) 1, (b) 2, and (c) 3). (right) Photographic images and UV–vis spectra of MO in water at various time intervals. (d) 1, (e) 2, and (f) 3.
elements.clean_text: 4  (left) Photographic images and UV-vis spectra of CR in water at various time intervals. (a) 1, (b) 2, and (c) 3). (right) Photographic images and UV-vis spectra of MO in water at various time intervals. (d) 1, (e) 2, and (f) 3.

elements.content: The adsorption mechanism between CR and MOFs could be explained by means of the structures of anion dyes and MOFs. MOFs can, in some instances, absorb organic dyes through strong interaction. As we know, the amide groups are both hydrogen-bonding donors and acceptors that can facilitate interactions with the specific dyes (). As shown in a, the peak of 1 observed at 1665 cm–1 is assigned to CO vibration of carboxylate groups. This peak shifted to 1658 cm–1 after CR adsorption. At the same time, the peak observed at 3463 cm–1 assigned to N–H vibration of NH2 from CR shifted to 3441 cm–1 after CR adsorption. For 2, the peak 1627 cm–1 of CO vibration shifted to 1620 cm–1, and 3463 cm–1 of N–H vibration shifted to 3452 cm–1, while there was no obvious change of 3 (b,c). Thus, we considered hydrogen bonds between the −NH2 groups (from CR) and the uncoordinated oxygen atoms in carboxyl groups of 1 and uncoordinated carboxyl groups of 2 play a key role in adsorbing CR.
elements.clean_text: The adsorption mechanism between CR and MOFs could be explained by means of the structures of anion dyes and MOFs. MOFs can, in some instances, absorb organic dyes through strong interaction. As we know, the amide groups are both hydrogen-bonding donors and acceptors that can facilitate interactions with the specific dyes (). As shown in a, the peak of 1 observed at 1665 cm-1 is assigned to CO vibration of carboxylate groups. This peak shifted to 1658 cm-1 after CR adsorption. At the same time, the peak observed at 3463 cm-1 assigned to N-H vibration of NH2 from CR shifted to 3441 cm-1 after CR adsorption. For 2, the peak 1627 cm-1 of CO vibration shifted to 1620 cm-1, and 3463 cm-1 of N-H vibration shifted to 3452 cm-1, while there was no obvious change of 3 (b,c). Thus, we considered hydrogen bonds between the -NH2 groups (from CR) and the uncoordinated oxygen atoms in carboxyl groups of 1 and uncoordinated carboxyl groups of 2 play a key role in adsorbing CR.

elements.content: Binding mechanism between CR dye and MOFs.
elements.clean_text: 5  Binding mechanism between CR dye and MOFs.

elements.content: IR spectra of dyes, the samples before and after the absorption of complex 1 (a), 2 (b, d), and 3 (c).
elements.clean_text: 6  IR spectra of dyes, the samples before and after the absorption of complex 1 (a), 2 (b, d), and 3 (c).

elements.content: However, the adsorption mechanism between MO and 2 is different. In general, MOFs are unlike inorganic porous materials due to flexible frameworks; their structures may change a little with strong interaction with adsorbates. As shown in d, the IR spectrum of 2 did not change before and after absorption of MO. But 2 readily adsorbs MO suggesting a strong interaction between the MO and the structure of 2, which may be attributed to physical forces.
elements.clean_text: However, the adsorption mechanism between MO and 2 is different. In general, MOFs are unlike inorganic porous materials due to flexible frameworks; their structures may change a little with strong interaction with adsorbates. As shown in d, the IR spectrum of 2 did not change before and after absorption of MO. But 2 readily adsorbs MO suggesting a strong interaction between the MO and the structure of 2, which may be attributed to physical forces.

elements.content: For comparison, the uncoordinated carboxyl groups of 2 can form hydrogen bond with amide groups of CR; moreover, there is a strong interaction between MO and 2, resulting in the good absorbtion capacity for CR and MO. But 1 only absorbed CR due to the uncoordinated oxygen atoms in carboxyl groups. However, there are no uncoordinated functional groups in the structure of 3 that lead to rare absorption of CR or MO.
elements.clean_text: For comparison, the uncoordinated carboxyl groups of 2 can form hydrogen bond with amide groups of CR; moreover, there is a strong interaction between MO and 2, resulting in the good absorbtion capacity for CR and MO. But 1 only absorbed CR due to the uncoordinated oxygen atoms in carboxyl groups. However, there are no uncoordinated functional groups in the structure of 3 that lead to rare absorption of CR or MO.

elements.content: Herein, we reported three Co-MOFs with high stability constructed by a “Y”-shaped carboxyl acid, which show different adsorption capacity for CR and MO. Mechanism study demonstrated that uncoordinated oxygen atoms in carboxyl groups and uncoordinated carboxyl groups played a significant role in the adsorbing anionic dyes. Besides, physical forces also affect adsorbing capacity.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

Herein, we reported three Co-MOFs with high stability constructed by a "Y"-shaped carboxyl acid, which show different adsorption capacity for CR and MO. Mechanism study demonstrated that uncoordinated oxygen atoms in carboxyl groups and uncoordinated carboxyl groups played a significant role in the adsorbing anionic dyes. Besides, physical forces also affect adsorbing capacity.

Symmetry code: No. 1 = x - 1, y, z, No. 2 = -x + 2, -y + 2, -z + 1, No. 3 = -x + 2, -y + 1, -z + 2, No. 4 = x + 1, y, z, No. 5 = -x + 1, -y + 1, -z, No. 6 = -x + 1, -y, -z. (b) The 3D framework of 3 and different connected mode of BPY ligands. (c) A view of 3,4,6-connected topology.

metadata.title:
Three Highly Stable Cobalt MOFs Based on “Y”-Shaped
